clusters.title: Crisis engulfs Labour as Angela Rayner is forced to step down as deputy PM
clusters.neutral_headline: Starmer Launches Cabinet Reshuffle After Deputy's Resignation

items.title: Crisis engulfs Labour as Angela Rayner is forced to step down as deputy PM
items.standfirst: Starmer brings forward cabinet reshuffle to restore order but fallout likely to further damage party’s reputationKeir Starmer is battling to get a grip on the crisis that has engulfed his government, with his deputy prime minister Angela Rayner forced to step down after breaching the ministerial code over her tax arrangements.The prime minister brought forward a major cabinet reshuffle in an attempt to restore order and get back on the front foot after a damaging few days, with Yvette Cooper, David Lammy and Shabana Mahmood all moved to prominent new roles. Continue reading...
items.content: Starmer brings forward cabinet reshuffle to restore order but fallout likely to further damage party’s reputationKeir Starmer is battling to get a grip on the crisis that has engulfed his government, with his deputy prime minister Angela Rayner forced to step down after breaching the ministerial code over her tax arrangements.The prime minister brought forward a major cabinet reshuffle in an attempt to restore order and get back on the front foot after a damaging few days, with Yvette Cooper, David Lammy and Shabana Mahmood all moved to prominent new roles. Continue reading...

items.title: Angela Rayner resigns after underpaying tax on Hove flat
items.standfirst: Her departure comes after the PM's ethics adviser concludes that she breached ministerial rules.
items.content: Her departure comes after the PM's ethics adviser concludes that she breached ministerial rules.

items.title: UK's Starmer overhauls his cabinet after deputy PM resigns amid tax scandal
items.standfirst: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Friday undertook the first major reshuffle of his cabinet since coming to power in July 2024, after deputy premier Angela Rayner resigned following a tax scandal. Her departure comes as Starmer's Labour government has been struggling to achieve its main goal of firing up Britain's economy.
items.content: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer on Friday undertook the first major reshuffle of his cabinet since coming to power in July 2024, after deputy premier Angela Rayner resigned following a tax scandal. Her departure comes as Starmer's Labour government has been struggling to achieve its main goal of firing up Britain's economy.

items.title: David Lammy named UK deputy prime minister amid Labour Party turmoil
items.standfirst: Lammy appointment follows resignation of left-wing champion Angela Rayner, who stepped down over a tax scandal.
items.content: Lammy appointment follows resignation of left-wing champion Angela Rayner, who stepped down over a tax scandal.

items.title: Watch: Key moments from Rayner's political career
items.standfirst: Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner has resigned after failing to pay enough tax on a flat in Hove.
items.content: Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner has resigned after failing to pay enough tax on a flat in Hove.

items.title: Tax scandal sinks U.K. deputy leader in huge blow to embattled PM Keir Starmer
items.standfirst: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.
items.content: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer's Labour Party deputy Angela Rayner resigned Friday after admitting underpaying property taxes.

items.title: Angela Rayner: The Tax Tangle Continues!
items.standfirst: The Prime Minister refuses to say if he’ll sack his deputy, if she broke the rules.
items.content: The Prime Minister refuses to say if he’ll sack his deputy, if she broke the rules.

ai_summary: Angela Rayner resigned as deputy prime minister after breaching ministerial code.
Keir Starmer initiated a cabinet reshuffle to restore order within the government.
Yvette Cooper moved to the Foreign Office, David Lammy became deputy PM.
Shabana Mahmood was appointed Home Secretary in the reshuffle.
The reshuffle followed Rayner's departure due to tax arrangement issues.

items.title: Putin says foreign troops in Ukraine would be legitimate targets
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Friday thousands of foreign troops could be deployed to his country under post-war security guarantees, but Russian leader Vladimir Putin said Moscow would regard them as legitimate targets to attack.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said on Friday thousands of foreign troops could be deployed to his country under post-war security guarantees, but Russian leader Vladimir Putin said Moscow would regard them as legitimate targets to attack.

items.title: Western troops in Ukraine would be ‘legitimate targets’, Putin says
items.standfirst: Russian president’s threat follows French proposal for postwar support for Kyiv that would include presence of Nato countries’ forcesVladimir Putin has said any western troops placed in Ukraine would be “legitimate targets” for Russian strikes, upping the stakes as Kyiv’s allies scramble to come up with a convincing offer of postwar support to Ukraine.Speaking a day after the French president, Emmanuel Macron, announced still-vague plans for a package of support for Ukraine backed by 26 nations, Putin on Friday said any guarantees that involved boots on the ground would violate Moscow’s longstanding objections to Nato troops in Ukraine. Continue reading...
items.content: Russian president’s threat follows French proposal for postwar support for Kyiv that would include presence of Nato countries’ forcesVladimir Putin has said any western troops placed in Ukraine would be “legitimate targets” for Russian strikes, upping the stakes as Kyiv’s allies scramble to come up with a convincing offer of postwar support to Ukraine.Speaking a day after the French president, Emmanuel Macron, announced still-vague plans for a package of support for Ukraine backed by 26 nations, Putin on Friday said any guarantees that involved boots on the ground would violate Moscow’s longstanding objections to Nato troops in Ukraine. Continue reading...

items.title: Putin warns Western troops in Ukraine would be 'legitimate target' for Moscow
items.standfirst: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said any foreign troops operating as part of a peacekeeping force in Ukraine would be considered a "legitimate target" by Moscow.
items.content: Russian President Vladimir Putin has said any foreign troops operating as part of a peacekeeping force in Ukraine would be considered a "legitimate target" by Moscow.

items.title: Putin says foreign troops in Ukraine would be "legitimate targets"
items.standfirst: "If any troops appear there, especially now while fighting is ongoing, we assume that they will be legitimate targets," Putin says as the U.S. and Europe plan for a post-war Ukraine.
items.content: "If any troops appear there, especially now while fighting is ongoing, we assume that they will be legitimate targets," Putin says as the U.S. and Europe plan for a post-war Ukraine.

items.content: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was questioned by senators from both parties on Thursday about vaccine access and more. NPR analyzes the health secretary's nearly three-hour appearance.

items.title: Trump remains vague on backing for Ukraine security plan
items.standfirst: Although Donald Trump joined in on a phone conversation with European leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky during the so called 'Coalition of the Willing' meeting, led by Emmanuel Macron in Paris, his level of backing for a post-war security plan remains undetermined.
items.content: Although Donald Trump joined in on a phone conversation with European leaders and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky during the so called 'Coalition of the Willing' meeting, led by Emmanuel Macron in Paris, his level of backing for a post-war security plan remains undetermined.

clusters.title: Employers added 22,000 jobs in August, falling short of forecasts
clusters.neutral_headline: U.S. Job Growth Slows, Adding 22,000 Jobs in August

items.title: Employers added 22,000 jobs in August, falling short of forecasts
items.standfirst: The latest employment data could inform the Federal Reserve's next rate decision meeting, set for Sept. 17.
items.content: The latest employment data could inform the Federal Reserve's next rate decision meeting, set for Sept. 17.

items.title: Weak Jobs Data Fuels Pressure On Fed To Cut Rates
items.standfirst: The U.S. job market slowed sharply in August, signaling deeper cracks in the economy under President Donald Trump’s trade and immigration policies. Employers added only 22,000 jobs, far below forecasts of 80,000, the Labor Department reported Friday. The unemployment rate rose to 4.3%, the highest…
items.content: The U.S. job market slowed sharply in August, signaling deeper cracks in the economy under President Donald Trump’s trade and immigration policies. Employers added only 22,000 jobs, far below forecasts of 80,000, the Labor Department reported Friday. The unemployment rate rose to 4.3%, the highest…

items.title: Labor Market Stalled This Summer, With August Data Adding to Slowdown
items.standfirst: Employers added 22,000 jobs in August. Revised data also showed that employment fell by 13,000 jobs in June, the first net loss since December 2020.
items.content: Employers added 22,000 jobs in August. Revised data also showed that employment fell by 13,000 jobs in June, the first net loss since December 2020.

items.title: US added just 22,000 jobs in August, continuing slowdown amid Trump tariffs
items.standfirst: Latest report also contained more bad news – the US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to latest surveyThe US jobs market stalled over the summer, adding just 22,000 jobs in August and continuing a slowdown in the labor market as businesses adjusted to disruptions caused by tariffs.The latest jobs report also contained more bad news. The US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to the latest survey, the first time it went into the negative since December 2020.Federal employment dropped 15,000 jobs in August, totaling 97,000 jobs lost since January.Manufacturing jobs went down by 12,000 in August and have tumbled 78,000 for the year.The racial unemployment gap widened in August. Black Americans are seeing an unemployment rate of 7.5%, compared to 6.1% last August. The unemployment rate for White Americans is 3.7% Continue reading...
items.content: Latest report also contained more bad news – the US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to latest surveyThe US jobs market stalled over the summer, adding just 22,000 jobs in August and continuing a slowdown in the labor market as businesses adjusted to disruptions caused by tariffs.The latest jobs report also contained more bad news. The US lost 13,000 jobs in June, according to the latest survey, the first time it went into the negative since December 2020.Federal employment dropped 15,000 jobs in August, totaling 97,000 jobs lost since January.Manufacturing jobs went down by 12,000 in August and have tumbled 78,000 for the year.The racial unemployment gap widened in August. Black Americans are seeing an unemployment rate of 7.5%, compared to 6.1% last August. The unemployment rate for White Americans is 3.7% Continue reading...

items.title: The U.S. added only 22,000 jobs last month, showing cracks in the labor market
items.standfirst: The U.S. job market showed more signs of weakness Friday, as the Labor Department reported just 22,000 jobs added in August. Revised figures show the economy lost jobs in June, and the unemployment rate inched up to 4.3%.
items.content: The U.S. job market showed more signs of weakness Friday, as the Labor Department reported just 22,000 jobs added in August. Revised figures show the economy lost jobs in June, and the unemployment rate inched up to 4.3%.(Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)

ai_summary: The U.S. economy added only 22,000 jobs in August, falling short of forecasts.
The unemployment rate rose to 4.3 percent, according to the Labor Department.
Revised data showed a loss of 13,000 jobs in June.
Federal employment dropped by 15,000 jobs in August.
The racial unemployment gap widened in August.

clusters.title: Google fined $3.5 billion by European Union over ad tech practices
clusters.neutral_headline: EU Fines Google $3.5 Billion for Ad Tech Practices

items.title: Google fined $3.5 billion by European Union over ad tech practices
items.standfirst: European Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a 2.95 billion euro ($3.5 billion) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company. The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s…
items.content: European Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a 2.95 billion euro ($3.5 billion) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company. The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s…

items.title: EU fines Google nearly €3bn for ‘abusing’ dominant position in ad tech
items.standfirst: Regulators ordered the tech giant to end ‘self-preferencing practices’ in advertising services but declined to force saleEuropean Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a €2.95bn ($3.5bn) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company as well as a retreat from previous threats to break up the tech giant.The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s executive branch and top antitrust enforcer, also ordered the US company to end its “self-preferencing practices” and take steps to stop “conflicts of interest” along the advertising technology supply chain. Continue reading...
items.content: Regulators ordered the tech giant to end ‘self-preferencing practices’ in advertising services but declined to force saleEuropean Union regulators on Friday hit Google with a €2.95bn ($3.5bn) fine for breaching the bloc’s competition rules by favoring its own digital advertising services, marking the fourth such antitrust penalty for the company as well as a retreat from previous threats to break up the tech giant.The European Commission, the 27-nation bloc’s executive branch and top antitrust enforcer, also ordered the US company to end its “self-preferencing practices” and take steps to stop “conflicts of interest” along the advertising technology supply chain. Continue reading...

items.title: Google Fined Almost €3 Billion by EU for Adtech Power Abuse
items.standfirst: Alphabet Inc.’s Google was fined almost €3 billion ($3.5 billion) by the European Union and ordered to stop favoring its own advertising technology services, in a move that risks further inflaming tensions with US President Donald Trump.
items.content: Alphabet Inc.’s Google was fined almost €3 billion ($3.5 billion) by the European Union and ordered to stop favoring its own advertising technology services, in a move that risks further inflaming tensions with US President Donald Trump.

ai_summary: The European Union fined Google $3.5 billion for antitrust violations.
Google was penalized for favoring its own advertising services.
The EU ordered Google to end "self-preferencing" practices.
This is Google's fourth antitrust penalty from the EU.
The EU also ordered Google to stop conflicts of interest.

items.title: Trump sends 10 stealth fighter planes to Puerto Rico amid war on Caribbean drug cartels
items.standfirst: Move comes after accusing Venezuela of buzzing US warship and a deadly US missile strike in Caribbean SeaDonald Trump is sending 10 F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico to bolster US military operations against drug cartels in the Caribbean region, it was reported on Friday.If follows a deadly US missile strike on Tuesday on a boat in the Caribbean Sea that the Trump administration insisted was carrying 11 Venezuelan drug traffickers, and comments by the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, on Wednesday that such attacks “will happen again”. Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. deploying 10 fighter jets to Puerto Rico in drug cartel crackdown

items.title: US deploys fighter jets to Puerto Rico to combat drug cartels amid tensions with Venezuela
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump is deploying 10 F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico to intensify the fight against drug cartels, sources said Friday. This comes as the US intensifies its military operations in the Caribbean, stoking tensions with Venezuela, which the US accuses of "narcoterrorism".
items.content: US President Donald Trump is deploying 10 F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico to intensify the fight against drug cartels, sources said Friday. This comes as the US intensifies its military operations in the Caribbean, stoking tensions with Venezuela, which the US accuses of "narcoterrorism".

items.content: The 10 F-35 fighter jets are being deployed to the Caribbean for operations targeting drug cartels, one source said.

ai_summary: The U.S. is deploying ten F-35 fighter jets to Puerto Rico.
The deployment is part of a crackdown on drug cartels.
The move follows tensions with Venezuela.
The U.S. accused Venezuela of "narcoterrorism."
The jets will support military operations in the Caribbean.
